repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development project is modest; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. Some lessons learnt from the project: included
            1) the need for interagency cooperation at border cross
            points to sustain changes and promote pragmatic approaches
            in problem resolution; 2) the multiplying effect of economic
            returns that come from replicating procedures at pilot
            sites; 3) the frequent rotation of staff in the General
            Directorate of Customs that made it difficult for the
            organization to "own" the project, and contributed
            to project delays; 4) the better results in detecting
            irregularities that come with customs control; 5) the need
            for further cooperation and support from government agencies
            to make the regional website sustainable and successful; 6)
            designing border inspection facilities as multifunctional so
            they could be adapted for other uses after their current use
            becomes no more relevant; 7) the need for the Bank to focus
            on legitimate security arrangements and anti-terrorism
            aspects as well as trade facilitation; 8) the fact that
            project was result-oriented  with measurable indicators
            contributed to project success; 9) the importance of
            starting the policy dialogue at the very beginning of the
            project; and 10) achieving better project results by
            adopting a regional approach, which creates peer pressure
            among participating countries and generates competitive
            spirit and motivation, leading to better performance.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            Southeast Europe Project, aims at strengthening, and
            modernizing customs administrations, and border control
            agencies in Albania, (and other countries in the region),
            seeking to reduce non-tariff costs to trade, and transport,
            reduce smuggling, and corruption at border crossings, in a
            collaborative effort between the Government of Albania
            (GOA), the European Union (EU), the United States of America
            (USA), and the Bank. The project components are: 1) Reform
            of customs services procedures, through monitoring, and
            revision procedures, to refine productivity indicators,
            enabling international standards. Training of customs staff
            will address particularly veterinary, and phyto-sanitary
            issues, including training to police, judges, and other
            officials involved in customs prosecutions. 2) Strengthening
            of private-public partnerships, through the establishment of
            a web-site supporting the program, to act as a focal point
            for trade facilitation; it includes training and expert
            services. 3) Support for an integrated customs information
            system, through the supply, and installation of hardware,
            and local/wide area networks at customs sites. 4)
            Improvement of roads, and border-crossing facilities,
            through the rehabilitation of existing stations, including
            design, and supervision works. 5) Operating, training, and
            consulting services will be financed by the USA, the Bank,
            and GOA.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The review of the project components for
            the Trade and Transportation Facilitation in Southeast
            Europe Project for Albania indicated that the project is
            unlikely to have significant adverse environmental impacts
            and is accordingly confirmed as a category B project. To
            prevent, minimize, or mitigate site specific negative
            impacts, however, this environmental management plan (EMP)
            and a set of mitigation measures have been prepared. The
            major concerns about possible negative site specific impacts
            associated with border crossings relate to 1) emissions from
            vehicles waiting for custom clearances; 2) drainage of
            disinfectants and spills of oils and fuel; 3) waste disposal
            and loose garbage; and 4) site disruptions caused by
            upgrades or relocations of utilities or such infrastructure
            as buildings, parking/waiting areas, and access roads.
            Specific actions to minimize any potentially negative impact
            and promote institutional development include liaising with
            environmental authorities and reviewing and monitoring EMP
            compliance; staff training and sensitization at each border
            crossing; certifying acceptable practices and impact
            minimization, especially storing and properly using
            disinfecting materials and chemicals, and hazardous
            materials and garbage; harmonizing regulatory requirements
            with European Union and international standards; and
            incorporating environmental plans in consultant contracts
            and project design.
